transcript:
Gloria Groom: Welcome! My name is Gloria Groom and I’m Chair of the Department of European Painting and Sculpture. We’re really excited to be presenting the Monet exhibition. We have had Monet exhibitions in the past but this is the first time to really focus on the artist and his impact on the city of Chicago and at the Art Institute. We’ll be talking about those important early collectors of Monet—the Palmers, the Ryersons, the Coburns—and, of course, other collectors throughout the 20th century. But we also want to be able to reveal some of the discoveries that have been made in the Conservation Lab with conservators and curators and art historians as we’ve looked very deeply and closely at his paintings. It’s really a celebration of the artist but also the history we’ve had with the artist in the city of Chicago.

So in the next room what you’ll see are photographs of the three most important collectors of Monet early on—how they lived with his paintings, how they looked, a little biography on them—to really get you into the story that Monet was not necessarily a household name but he was certainly appreciated by the leaders of the Chicago cultural life of that time
